thread.title: New York's LaGuardia Airport airport to be rebuilt
thread.title_full: New York's LaGuardia Airport airport to be rebuilt

title: New York's LaGuardia Airport airport to be rebuilt
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Mon, Jul 27, 2015, 21:28 BST - UK Markets closed New York's LaGuardia Airport airport to be rebuilt AFP â€“ 12 minutes ago View Photo 

New York's LaGuardia Airport, famously likened to a "third world country" by Vice President Joe Biden, is to be rebuilt from the ground up, officials announced Monday. 
"We want a globally renowned airport for the next century that is worthy of the name New York," Governor Andrew Cuomo announced in a Manhattan hotel ballroom alongside Biden. 
The Guide to Sleeping in Airports rated LaGuardia as the 10th worst airport in the world in 2014, singling out security lines, drab decor, lackluster cleanliness and unhelpful staff. 
Construction will be financed by a $4 billion private-public partnership and will create around 8,000 new jobs, officials said. 
The initial phase of construction is slated to begin in the first half of 2016. Cuomo said lengthy approval processes had been expedited by the vice president's office. 
The new airport will move 600 feet (183 meters) closer to the Grand Central Parkway, creating more space for flight operations and will eventually be linked up to the rail network. 
Cuomo called the current airport "un-New York." 
"It's slow, dated and a terrible entranceway to New York," he said. 
Biden added: "This is the greatest city in the world... It requires a 21st century infrastructure." 
LaGuardia first opened in 1939 and was originally constructed by the city of New York at a cost of $40 million. Last year, nearly 27 million passengers passed through the airport. 
That number is expected to grow to 34 million passengers by 2030, Biden said. 
Cuomo said his administration would also design a master plan for New York's busiest hub, John F. Kennedy International Airport, that would be done in the next 12 months. 
JFK last year processed 53 million passengers. New York, home to 8.4 million people, is America's biggest city, the country's financial and entertainment capitals. 
In 2013, the city received 54.3 million international and domestic visitors.
